> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/22288?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [e2e1a10...9ed681c](https://codecov.io/gh/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/22288?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
Should be ready for a look @jbrockmendel
This may be a hassle to check, but does `ts` match before the `to_period` call?
Hmm not sure I quite understand @jbrockmendel. Check that `ts` matches what before the `to_period` call?

> Check that ts matches what before the to_period call?

The issue is that `ts.to_period('D')` on Appveyor does not `ts.to_period('D')` locally right?  So my question was if `ts` on Appveyor matches `ts` locally.

> Okay so this looks like a tzlocal discrepancy:

OK next question: what timezone is the appveyor instance in?  what timezone is the local machine in?  If they aren't the same, then that explains why tzlocal would be different.

My local is `US/Pacific`, and it looks like AppVeyor is in a timezone where there's a daylight savings transition on March 11, 2000.

However, I think test in particular is mainly trying to test if `to_period` works for different timezone types (pytz and dateutil) and not necessarily concerned with dst transitions, so I ended up shortening the generated date_range to not hit that transition.

1) It looks like `DateOffset` nor any of the subclasses exists in `api.rst`. I'll make an issue to include them (including `CalendarOffset`)

2) RE dst_tz_fitxure: I think the existing `tz_aware_fixture` should include `tzlocal` and others, but I suspect it may break some existing tests, so I think that'll be a good follow up.
ping @jbrockmendel @chris-b1

Thanks for the feedback @jbrockmendel @chris-b1 

All green minus an unrelated build failure seen in https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/22499
@jreback all green.
@jreback Addressed your comments and all green.

Hello @mroeschke! Thanks for updating the PR.

 - There are no PEP8 issues in the file [`pandas/core/arrays/datetimes.py`](https://github.com/mroeschke/pandas/blob/9ed681c9bba45ac2f939e85951127de569ae28c7/pandas/core/arrays/datetimes.py) !

 - In the file [`pandas/core/indexes/datetimes.py`](https://github.com/mroeschke/pandas/blob/9ed681c9bba45ac2f939e85951127de569ae28c7/pandas/core/indexes/datetimes.py), following                are the PEP8 issues :
> [Line 389:17](https://github.com/mroeschke/pandas/blob/9ed681c9bba45ac2f939e85951127de569ae28c7/pandas/core/indexes/datetimes.py#L389): [W504](https://duckduckgo.com/?q=pep8%20W504) line break after binary operator
> [Line 390:17](https://github.com/mroeschke/pandas/blob/9ed681c9bba45ac2f939e85951127de569ae28c7/pandas/core/indexes/datetimes.py#L390): [W504](https://duckduckgo.com/?q=pep8%20W504) line break after binary operator

##### Comment last updated on September 05, 2018 at 16:52 Hours UTC
@jreback made the requested changes and all green
thanks! @mroeschke nice addition

Sorry that I did not comment earlier (also didn't read all review comments), but I think this is a much bigger break in behaviour than we think / is documented. 

This completely changes the default behaviour of `date_range` when using tz aware dates:

Now on master:
```
In [4]: pd.date_range("2016-10-30", periods=4, tz='Europe/Helsinki')
Out[4]: 
DatetimeIndex(['2016-10-30 00:00:00+03:00', '2016-10-30 23:00:00+02:00',
               '2016-10-31 23:00:00+02:00', '2016-11-01 23:00:00+02:00'],
              dtype='datetime64[ns, Europe/Helsinki]', freq='D')
```

Previously:

```
In [6]: pd.date_range("2016-10-30", periods=4, tz='Europe/Helsinki')
Out[6]: 
DatetimeIndex(['2016-10-30 00:00:00+03:00', '2016-10-31 00:00:00+02:00',
               '2016-11-01 00:00:00+02:00', '2016-11-02 00:00:00+02:00'],
              dtype='datetime64[ns, Europe/Helsinki]', freq='D')
```

This also changed the inferring of freq (now '24H' instead of 'D'), changes the behaviour of `resample('D')`, ...
(I would personally revert this PR until we have better discussed it)

I left a https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/issues/22274#issuecomment-419549602 with the rational.


In terms of documentation, there's a section in the whatsnew v0.24 that notes this API change:

https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/70c9003c9e67c34fb31d4b6be8d8b970dfacbd38/doc/source/whatsnew/v0.24.0.txt#L288-L326

And new reference in `timeseries.rst` that discusses the difference between `Day` and `CalendarDay`

https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/master/doc/source/timeseries.rst#day-vs-calendarday

Yeah, there were certainly nice new docs about the CalendarDay, but the illustration of the changed behaviour was only for, IMO, a minor use case of arithmetic with offset objects, while the more relevant user-facing changes as date_range and resample were not mentioned.
That's a fair concern; I can certainly give more attention to this impact on `date_range` and `resample` in the whatsnew and the CalendarDay section in `timeseries.rst`
